transcripts.text: This is dumb.  Thomas is out of Michigan.  Thomas, thank you for calling.  Get it off your chest, sir.
Hey, Jesse, can you hear me?
Loud and clear, Thomas.  How are you doing?
I'm doing good.  I hope all is well.  I haven't talked to you in a minute.
No, man, it's good.
Jesse, the last few times I heard you, I heard a couple of lies.  you was telling, bro.
Tell me lies.  Tell me sweet little lies.
I thought you was an honest man.
Tell me lies.  Tell me lies.  Don't patronize.  Tell me lies.  Give me one lie you heard.
All right.  First of all, you said you told a caller.
Are you a Christian, Thomas?
Yes, sir.
Okay.  You believe in God?
All the way.
All right.  Tell me one lie you told.
You told a caller... This black guy was asking you about the Jim Crow laws.
Yes.

And you said they were created by black Democrats to, what did you say, that they made that to do something?  And I was like, that's a lie.  That wasn't made up.  They were made up by white Democratic Party, and it was controlled by the local state.
So you heard me say, I said black Democrats.
Yeah, because he said, well, who made that up?  Because he was talking about Jim Crow.  Was that evil or was it racism?
I may have had a slip of the tongue.  I'll go back and listen to that because sometimes people say I said things that I didn't say.  So why did you think Jim Crow was made?
I

did tell you that it was created by Democrats In order to control the people, to keep the people divided, it didn't quite work because in those good old days when black people had morals and they believed in God, they don't have it now, but when they had it, they knew that not all white people was for that.  And white people knew that not all black people for that.  And they got along.  But it was the Democratic Party, as they are today, created and carried out the so-called Jim Crow law.
But you said it was a good time.
It was for black people.  You mean for black people, right?
It was a bad time for black people.
No, it wasn't.  What was the bad time?
Black people, Jim Crow laws, we had to sit in the back of the bus.
That's bad.
We couldn't vote.
We couldn't use it.
Yeah, because they're treating you as a second-class citizen.  They're not treating you as an equal human being.
What is bad about sitting in the back of a bus?  That's the first plane that black people run to now.
If somebody tells me, yeah, because they got trained to do that over the years, young black kids.
So the black kids who are sitting in the back of the bus today were trained by Jim Crow to sit in the back?
Some of them was passed down with that and kids might think it's fun because they don't know.
Now you're lying.
They don't know the origin.
Now you're lying.
My parents and people your age know the origin.

People are sitting in the back of the bus because it's comfortable back there.  They don't have to have eyes.  Some people think that.  Some people are insecure and they don't need all eyes.  Let me finish.  No, let me finish.  They don't need all eyes looking on them, so they sit in the back.  Even at my church service.  You're making it sound good.  Hold on, man.  Let me put them all home.  People sit in the back of the bus because they don't want to be looked at and feel more comfortable.  Isn't that right, Joe?  So this man, Thomas Lyon again.
You always go to the back.

Yeah, you go to the back.  You looking at everybody else, nobody can see you.  In our church service, we have to invite the people to come down front, right?  So everybody end up in the back seats.  So Thomas Lyon, and nobody trained them that from Jim Crow, and that was passed down from black people.  What a liar.  Thomas Lyon with that nice name.  And then Thomas and the Bible, Thomas need to take it, come out the grave and take, Thomas, come out the grave and take your name back.  The Bible, Thomas.  Thomas, are you lying about that?
Hello, can I talk?
Not over me.
Can I speak now?
Go ahead.
Jesse, you, the way you try to deflect and say things is so ridiculous.  Jesse, they were telling you, boy, nigger, get to the back of the bus.
Who told you that?
Why do you think she stood up?  Why do you think Rosa Parks stood up and said, no more of this?
May I tell you why?
I can't go.  Did you have to sit up at the theater at the top and go through the back door?
It was fun.  So let me answer some of your questions first.  Number one, no one ever.  No, I have to think about it.  I grew up in it.  No one ever said.
I know you did.

No, I'm putting Thomas on hold.  You sound like a black woman.  You keep interrupting.  No one ever said, nigga, boy, get up and go to the back of the bus.  No one ever said that to me in my whole life.  And secondly, when I went to the movie theater once down in Eufaula, Alabama, we couldn't sit together with the white folks.  We had to sit in the balcony.  But I was a teenager.  That was fun.  That was not pain.  So he's lying about that.  Let's see what else.  Thomas, what else?
So you said I'm lying about all of that?
Yes.  Yes.
Okay, so you're never going to agree to me.  So I have another question.

Oh, let me tell you why.  Rosa Parks stood up on the bus and said, oh, I'm tired.  It was planned by the NAACP.  Rosa Parks was not one day coming home.  Nobody was aware.  And she just stood up.  Lord, I ain't going to sit in the back of this bus no more.  I'm just tired.  It didn't happen that way.  It was planned by the NAACP.  Okay?  And as a matter of fact, they had chosen another woman to do it.  And just before she did it, at some point, they found out that that black woman was pregnant out of wedlock.  They're like, uh-uh.  This ain't going to work.  Ain't nobody going to step in with some pregnant black woman trying to stand up and talk about she's tied.  They said, okay, we can't use her.  And they found Rosa Park to do it.  And they tried to portray it as though somehow or another, Rosa was just so tired.  And she would come home from work one day, and Rosa said, Lord, I ain't sending back of this bus anymore.  No more.  Yo, did you know it happened that way?
No, you just hear in schools that she was a hero.

She was not no hero.  She was a zero.  She was not a brave woman.  It was planned by the NAACP.  They knew what they were doing.  And so a brave woman would have just stood up with nobody looking, nobody protecting, nobody watching.  And if she was that upset about sitting at the back of a bus and said, y'all, I ain't sitting back here no more.  It was planned.
Shake my head.

And it was like that.  And the people had been lying to the blacks to keep them angry and used them.  Like, Thomas, he believe it.  And he's angry about nothing.  And then to scale white people into shutdown mode.  It's all the lie, folks.  It's the children of the lie lying to you.  It never happened, Joel.
And he mad like it happened to him.

Yeah, and he's talking about now.  these children are sitting in the back of the bus because it's been passed down.  Who passed it?  How can that be passed down to somebody?  Okay, kids, in 2019, y'all go sit in the back of the bus.  You can't make those kids sit up front.
What a mess, huh?  It's horrible.

All lies.  Ain't nobody out there cleaning it up but me.  It's all lies, folks.  I grew up in it.  I grew up on a Jim Crow.  Ain't nobody said niggas go to the back of the bus.  They didn't even say, nigga, go to the top in the movie theater.  We just went up there.  We saw the sign that led us up there.  We were fine.  I remember sitting up there.  We had a perfect view.  We were like, oh, white people are missing out.  They're down bottom.  They can't see.
And kids aren't even thinking about that.  They ain't thinking about going to the back of the bus because of some black stuff.

These black people are lying.  That's why it was a mistake.  I mean, not a mistake.  The worst thing, one of the worst things that ever happened to black people was the stupid civil rights movement.  The only thing that they should have done was pass the law, the same laws that the Democrats had organized that would get rid of those laws and let people be protected and then leave us alone.  Go set out.  We don't need no leaders.  We don't need no government.  We don't need no nothing.  We're doing just fine.  Thank you.  And then they set themselves up as leaders, other people.  And now black men don't even think for themselves.  Whatever they hear, that's what they say.  Anyway, where's Thomas?  Let's see what else he got to say.
Thomas!  Can you hear me, Jesse?
I can now, yes.
Tell the beta boy, Joel, I'm not angry.  I was just talking about history.
No, you're lying.
You change history, Jesse.  No, you lied about history.
It never happened.  You lied about history.  All that mess you talk about did not happen.
I'm just saying what history says.  Why would I lie about what history has done?
Because you believe what the liars wrote.
Okay, so here's another question.  And what they say.  Can I ask you another question?
One more.
Tariq Nasheed brought up that you were funded by Joseph Farrar.
Who is Joseph Farrar?
Radical Jewish homosexual.
Who is Joseph Farrar?
The founder, your funding of Bond.
Are you calling Joseph Farrar of the WND, you calling him a Jewish homosexual?
I'm saying, is he?
Are you saying that he is a Jew?
That's what came up online.
Are you saying that he's a Jewish homosexual?
I don't know.  I'm asking you, is he?  Is he your funder?
Why are you asking, is he?
I heard Tariq Nasheed say he was funding you and he was putting out propaganda.
Tariq lied about that.
He had you putting out racist propaganda.
He lied about that.  Black people lie, man.  You can't believe liars.
So we don't tell truth about nothing.
Nothing.  Y'all hate the truth.  Y'all are liars.
I don't hate the truth.
Y'all are liars.  Ain't no more.  Nothing lies.  Tell Tariq he's a liar about that.
